ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned new grammar structures, new vocabulary, and how to speak honorific Korean. I also learned irregular verb structures, which I had not learned before and had trouble with but eventually mastered.

My level of proficiency in Korean definitely increased, and it wasn't too difficult to pick it back up after I had taken a semester off of Korean. The class discussions were always very lively and helped my improve my fluency.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: A strength of the course was the structure that worksheets provided. I always left class feeling like I learned something new.

It was a very small class which both contributed and took away from it. There was a lot of professor attention, but then it was a morning class with very few students, so sometimes it was slow-moving if not everyone was awake. I think the class could be improved by having more readings that used the grammar, so we could get see more examples of sophisticated sentences.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I vastly improved my Korean speaking skill and the professor is very empathetic and considerate to the workload and troubles, academic or personal, of students.

Professor Lee-Smith is the reason why learning Korean is so easily facilitated and enjoyable. She creates a comfortable class environment and has incredibly strong relationships to her students through class and through home-cooking at language table every week.
